title: abbott better security tories
story: The arch leftie will say years of austerity, police cuts and bungling at the border show “Labour is the party of real security”.The claim comes despite Jeremy Corbyn’s peacenik past as chair of Stop the War and Ms Abbott’s opposition to stop and search powers for the cops.The Shadow Home Secretary will say: “The Government is big on rhetoric about security, policing and borders. But talk is cheap.“Action costs money. And they have slashed the border guards just like they have slashed the police and fire services.“Not Labour. It was the Tories that cut them all.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: british endurance cyclist mike hall inquest canberra australia
story: The 35-year-old from Harrogate was competing in the Indian Pacic Wheel Race across Australia when the tragedy unfolded on March 31, last year.The record-breaking cyclist suffered major head, spinal and abdominal injuries, the Coroners Court in the Australian Capital Territory was told.At the three-day inquest, which opened in Canberra yesterday, the court heard that the 19-year-old driver, Shegu Bobb, initially thought he had hit a kangaroo.The court was told that it was dark at the time of the crash at 6.22am and it would have been dficult for a motorist to see, according to Nine News.Hall was in second place in the coast-to-coast race, in which cyclists ride 3,400 miles from Perth to Sydney, when he as struck by the car travelling at 62mph.Counsel assisting the coroner Ken Archer said the event was known for its dficulties and likened to the Hunger Games on wheels.He said that Hall was wearing dark clothing with limited reflective qualities at the time of the collision.Mr Archer said: The bike was effectively impaled on the front of the car.The inquest was also played documentary footage of Hall racing at night in which he was visible.Mr Bobb, who was on his way to work at the time of the crash, has never been charged.The inquest heard he has suffered signicant distress and shock since the tragedy.Halls partner Anna Haslock was pictured arriving at the inquest after crowdfunding money to travel to Australia.Hall made headlines in 2012 when he broke the world record for a round the world ride, taking an incredible 91 days and 18 hours to traverse the entire globe.He had been living in Monmouthshire, South Wales, before his death.The inquest continues.

title: mum stands parking space 10 minutes reserve spot
story: Pulling into a spot at Westfield St Lukes Mall in Auckland, New Zealand, the driver of the people carrier was stunned to see the pair standing in his way, seemingly reserving the space.“It’s stupid… it’s not very good,” says the appalled driver who filmed the incident.Despite persistently honking his horn, the mum stands her ground and appears to carry on her phone conversation with her boy nervously hiding behind her.The driver continues: “Can you please move as this is a public car park and I would like to park my family’s vehicle here.According to a comment on the video, the pair moved after ten minutes.It has sparked much online debate as to who was in the right – the unwavering mum and boy or the determined driver.One Facebook user said: We all do that or have done that. Im sure he couldve parked elsewhere.But another added: Shes in the wrong and its the principle of the matter.But tooting your horn like that with a kid there is also wrong.A third wasnt so sympathetic, commenting: Get the frick out of his way blueberry, you dont have a car you dont get a park.

title: mh370 plane wreckage google maps matches ping
story: The Malaysian Airlines plane vanished on March 8, 2014, en route to Beijing from Kuala Lumper sparking one of the greatest mysteries in aviation history.Satellite company Inmarsat continued to exchange signals, known as “handshakes”, with the aircraft every hour before it crashed.The firm has now released data which maps out two radius zones – spanning thousands of miles – where MH370 could have travelled.One of the areas – known as the northern corridor – is where the satellite exchanged its last handshake with the troubled plane, reports the Daily Star.This vast radius zone runs through Cambodia – along with several other countries.Earlier this month, British sleuth Ian Wilson believes he found the wreckage of MH370 using Google Maps - despite millions being spent on the search for the jet.Video producer Wilson believes the plane is lying in a high-altitude area of the Cambodia jungle - 60 miles west of Phnom Penh.The Brit, who says he found the image of the plane after spending “hours” searching on his own computer, now wants to visit the site himself.After learning about Inmarsat’s data, Wilson told the Daily Star: “Initially I thought it crashed into the sea.But then theres the northern and southern corridors. That seventh ping is almost exactly where the plane is.The northern corridor runs from southern China to Uzbekistan – a zone which spans over 1,400 miles – while the southern arc runs through the Indian Ocean where parts of the plane have been found.Wilsons images from Google Maps show the outline of a large plane in a remote part of southern Cambodia  – which could simply be an aircraft flying directly below the satellite which photographed it.Following the Brits revelation, and with a £53million finders fee up for grabs, a group of experts hired a helicopter to scour the area highlighted by Wilson.However, on September 13, it was reported that the group had failed to find anything in the zone where Wilson believes the plane crashed.The Chinese government also used observation company Space View to focus in on the high-altitude area of the south east Asian country.However, the firm claim there was no sign of any plane, least of all the Malaysian Airlines aircraft.In a tweet, Space View wrote: “Stakeholders and bystanders plead Space View to shoot at the site.So we found out three images, shot in 2015, 2016 and 2018 from our archive.Sorry, no plane found there.In July this year, the Malaysian government released the findings of their investigation admitting they still do not know what happened to thepassenger jet.

title: significant shipwreck found portugal cascais
story: The team believe the ship was ing from India when it sank sometime between 1575 and 1625.Peppercorns, fragments of Chinese porcelain from the late 16th and early 17th centuries, as well as bronze cannons were all found among the sunken remains near Cascais, close to the country’s capital Lisbon.The wreck site, which sits about 12m  below the surface, is about 100m  long and 50m  wide.Project director Jorge Freire told Reuters that the wreck was very well-preserved.He said: From a heritage perspective, this is the discovery of the decade.“[It’s] the most important find of all time [for the country].”Finding wrecks off the Portuguese coast is very rare, especially when the objects are this well preserved.The teams say the discovery will shed light on both Portugal’s trading past and Cascais’s place within it.Freire added: “We found the ship on September 4 using a geophysical survey and ers, and spent four days working on the site.”The ship was found while dredging the mouth of the Tagus river, which runs past the resort town and through Lisbon.The mayor of Cascais Carlos Carreiras described the discovery as one of the most signicant archaeological finds of the past decade, the  reported.He said that although the cargo ship had yet to be identied, it could prove signicant to the town.The mayor said: “It’s an extraordinary discovery that allows us to know more about our history, reinforcing our collective identity and shared values.“That, in turn, will certainly make us more attractive and competitive.”In 1994, the wreck of Portuguese ship Our Lady of the Martyrs was discovered near Fort of Sao Juliao da Barra, a military defence complex near Cascais.Our Lady of the Martyrs also sailed the spice route and sank off Lisbon in 1606.According to the survey team, who have been mapping the areas since 2009, the latest wreck is in better structural shape.Minister of Culture Luis Mendes said: For a long time, specialists have considered the mouth of the Tagus River a hotspot for shipwrecks.This discovery came to prove it.The ship was found as part of a 10-year-old archaeological project backed by the town of Cascais, the Portuguese Government and navy, and Nova University of Lisbon.

title: terrifying moment boy 5 dangles by neck from 130ft ferris wheel after climbing out when he was allowed to travel alone
story: The boy is said to have tried to sit on the metal bars securing the open window of the Ferris wheel cabin when he slipped out.  Luckily he was caught by his neck and avoided plunging some 131 feet to his death.The heart-in-mouth moment happened on September 24 as the boy and his mum, known as Liu, visited the amusement park.But rather than pay the 30 RMB  on a ticket, she let her son ride alone after he repeatedly nagged her about it, with staff members reportedly allowing the oversight.As the boy’s car, number 18, reached the peak of the city landmark Ferris wheel, screams were heard from the ground as witnesses spotted the boy climbing out the window feet first.The shouting and screaming increased in intensity as the boy’s small body appeared to slip out the window between the metal security bars.Footage shows the boy desperately kicking his legs as he hangs by his neck, with no one in his car to help him back inside.When it became clear that the boy could not be helped, operators let the Ferris wheel continue to turn and waited as car 18 made its way to the ground agonisingly slowly.Staff members and other witnesses immediately rushed to the boy and freed him from the bars when he came within reach, the video shows.He and his mum were taken to the city’s First People’s Hospital, with the child fortunately suffering no serious injuries besides a bruised neck.City officials have reportedly shut down the Ferris wheel operations as investigations into the ordeal continue.A witness was quoted as saying: Children need to be accompanied by adults when riding the Ferris wheel. I don’t know how the mother convinced the staff members to let her son ride along in a car.Yuhuan Park’s amusement facilities were opened to the public in November 2013, the 137-foot Ferris wheel instantly becoming its main attraction and Taizhou’s new landmark.

title: far left teacher boasts that hes educating kids not to be tories in labour conference speech
story: Sion Rickard insisted that  kids get a “proper education”, the country “won’t have any Tories”.He sparked a furious backlash and was accused of trying to brainwash vulnerable children.Mr Rickard, a teaching assistant, made an appearance on the main stage of the conference yesterday when delegates were debating education.He said: “Ive never met a bad four-year-old. Ive never met a four-year-old that was evil.“So every child has a chance and  we give them a proper education, well empty our prisons, well have much less problems with our NHS, social issues.“Well probably not have any Tories because well have brought up our kids properly.”His rant was met with a rapturous response as activists cheered and applauded from the floor of the conference hall.But Mr Rickard was blasted for forcing his political agenda on schoolchildren.Tory MP Nigel Evans told MailOnline: “Its frightening to think that this guy is let loose in classrooms.“There was clearly a mal in his own education which seriously needs investigating.”

title: british army photo of the year
story: The often gritty and eye-opening pictures have been snapped by professional Army photographers, as well as regular personnel keen to capture their lives.They make up a shortlist of 14 amazing images, chosen from more than 1,000 submitted shots for this years contest.Each picture gives a glimpse into Army le, showing British soldiers working hard and enjoying their time off.They include photos of soldiers boxing, on parade, taking part in exercises and being reunited with their families.One picture shows a soldier and his family ing home, after completing six months of training and mentoring Security Forces in Iraq.Another heartwarming image shows five-year-old Alfie Warren with his Father Cpl Andrew Warren, after the Royal Scots Dragoon Guards  paraded following a UN Cyprus six month deployment.It is up to the public to decide which picture should be the winner, and crowned photograph of the year.Armys command master photographer, WO1 Will Craig, who chose the shortlist, said: Weve had signicant more entries into this years competition, and the quality of photographs has increased once more.From all of the categories, we have seen a wide range of activities that the Army has been involved in during the past year.Allowing the general public an opportunity to enter the competition, shows the Army from their perspective.View the photos and vote until 12pm on Tuesday, October 9.The Imperial War Museum in London will host the Awards Ceremony on Wednesday, October 17.Earlier this week we reported on pictures of Royal Navy heroes taking part in missions across the world won a prestigious photography competition.The images show submarine operations in the North Pole and emotional homecoming scenes on windswept jetties.Each picture was taken by a Royal Navy photographer responsible for telling the stories of sailors and Royal Marines through a camera lens.

title: vladimir putin party local election battering ldpr
story: Vlad’s ruling United Russia were beaten badly in a pair of regional votes by the crackpot Liberal Democratic Party of Russia .The shock results come amid widespread anger over the government plan to increase the national retirement age.In the far east region of Khabarovsk, the LDPR won the governor’s seat with a massive 70 per cent of the vote while the Putin-backed candidate received just under 28 per cent.The anti-western party also scored an upset in the run-off election for governor of the Vladimir region near Moscow, beating United Russia by more than 20 per cent.Bizarrely in that race, the LDPR candidate Vladimir Sipyagin won despite barely campaigning – such is the growing animosity towards Putin’s regime, reports The Times.The LDPR is led by the eccentric Vladimir Zhirinovsky – described widely as the “clown prince” of Russian politics.In the past, the 72-year-old has urged Putin to drop nuclear bombs on the US-backed Baltic countries and Turkey, with whom Russia has clashed with over the Syrian conflict.During his 1993 presidential election campaign Zhirinovsky pledged to provide free vodka, better lingerie for women and legalise polygamy.He also promised to clone famous Russians such as composer Pyotr Tchaikovsky.In an example of his anti-western rhetoric, Zhirinovsky once threatened to change the gravitational field of the Earth in order to sink the United States of America, reports Vice.In the tirade against the invasion of Iraq in 2002, he called the US a “second-hand goods store” filled with “c**ksuckers, handj*****s, and f***ers.”In 2006, following the poisoning death of Russian defector Alexander Litvinenko in London, Zhirinovsky said: Any traitor must be eliminated using any methods.If you have joined the special services to work, then you should work, but to betray, to run away abroad, to give up the secrets you learned while working – all of this looks bad.Activist and Putin critic Ilya Yashin said the LDPR’s success is directly related to the electorate’s anger towards the government.He said: “People want to get rid of United Russia so badly that they are ready to vote for the representative of a party of clowns.“The people are fed up.”Earlier this month, Zhirinovsky was filmed punching a man in the face at a packed political rally in Moscow.In video footage of the incident, the party leader is heard shouting at a young man: I will punch you and you will bleed” before attacking him.The victim had reportedly called the controversial MP a s***.Zhirinovsky’s son Igor Lebedev, who is an MP for the LDPR, has openly supported the country’s football hooligans in the past.Following the violent scenes at matches involving Russian thugs during Euro 2016, Lebedev said: “I don’t see anything wrong with the fans fighting. Quite the opposite: well done our lads, keep it up!”He made the astonishing remarks while being a member of the Russian Football Union executive committee.According to the FT, he later said: “I don’t think our fans did anything over the top, and you need to understand that, nine times out of 10, football supporters come to a game to fight, and that’s normal.”

title: female dentist bombarded woman medic love letters
story: Cosmetic dentist Daniella Todorova-Besarbova, 52, was married and had never had a lesbian relationship when she allegedly became fixated with the medic.Cheltenham Magistrates Court heard a stash of pictures of the medic was found on her computer and she had been researching stalking laws when she was arrested.Todorova-Besarbova, from Gloucester, was set to face a two-day trial after pleading not guilty to stalking the married woman, causing her serious alarm or distress.But as the trial was set to begin, the prosecution offered not to proceed with the case when the defendant agreed to accept an indefinite restraining order banning her from contacting her alleged victim.Todorova-Besarbova was told by the magistrates: You cannot make someone elses le a misery again.She replied: I understand.The court was told the stalking campaign lasted for nearly two years, between December 2015 and September 2017.Prosecuting, Matthew Jackson said the pair met professionally in 2014 but Todorova-Besarbova began to pester the medic after she refused to go for a coffee with her.He said: A Facebook friends request then appeared from the defendant to the complainant. Several Facebook messages were also sent by the defendant.On 28th April 2016 the defendant told the complainant she was going back to Bulgaria to get a orce. She asked questions about [the medics] personal le, whether she was happy, etc.She again asked her to go for a coffee with her and this was again declined.Mr Jackson said Todorova-Besarbova saw the medic again on May 13, 2016 and produced a love letter which she handed over for the complainants consideration.The court heard in the letter she said she had agreed orce terms with her husband and would be free in three months, adding I will wait for you.The dentist was said to have written: You are the only person I have ever wanted to spend my le with. I have never been in love with a woman before. You are the first in my le. Love Daniella.The court was told Todorova-Besarbova also sat outside the medics workplace for hours at a time and turned up outside her home address on a number of occasions.Mr Matthews said the complainant had made a statement saying she felt extremely shocked and disturbed when Todorova-Besarbova first professed her love for her.A statement read to the court from the alleged victim, said: I have had nightmares, including one about finding the defendant in my home.I still do not understand what led her to fixate on me. I wonder now  I should be less approachable and open than I usually am.I will not feel safe unless there is a robust and indefinite injunction to protect myself and my family from her.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle in first solo royal engagement today as bitter sister samantha heads to uk for showdown
story: The Duchess of Sussex is attending the opening of an art exhibition this evening in central London.The 37-year-old is set to join guests from 6.15pm to see works from the Oceania region, at the Royal Academy of Arts in central London.The exhibition celebrates the art of Melanesia, Micronesia and Polynesia, encompassing the vast Pacic region including New Guinea, Easter Island, Hawaii and New Zealand.It marks the first time she will officially be at an engagement without not only her husband, but any other member of the royal family.Her appearance comes hours after her estranged half-sisters publicist confirmed that she is “coming to the UK this week, like it or not”.The 53-year-old was in Italy and posted a picture of herself at an airport on Saturday, writing “new profile pic”.PR manager Rob Cooper also posted a picture of him with Samantha and wrote: “Samantha Markle is coming to the UK.“After making numerous attempts in private to arrange a one on one meeting with The Duchess of Sussex to discuss their 74 year old father’s health, Kensington Palace have refused to respond.“I fear Meghan may not be made aware of these discreet attempts and therefore making this public is the only option we have left.“I currently have Samantha in Europe with just one short flight away. This DOESN’T need to be public, we would prefer to keep this private.“Samantha is coming to the UK this week, like it or not.”Kensington Palace declined to comment when approached by The Sun Online last night.Meghan, who married on May 19, will take part in her first royal event by herself four months after becoming a member of the monarchy.The Duchess of Cambridge carried out her first solo engagement, standing in for the Prince of Wales at a private fundraising dinner, in October 2011, almost six months after her wedding day.The exhibition marks the 250th anniversary of the Royal Academy, which was founded in 1768, the year Captain James Cook set out on his first Endeavour expedition.Meghan and Harry are due to tour Australia, Tonga, Fiji and New Zealand in October and the duchess will be shown art from the four countries during her exhibition viewing.She will meet the exhibitions curators, artists and descendants linked to the works on display, and view a short performance by Ngati Ranana, a Maori cultural group.Oceania at the Royal Academy of Arts will open to the public from September 29 to December 10.

title: wifi cash machines and buses should all be free in britains towns to revive struggling high streets labour claims
story: The Shadow Business Secretary also said young people should get free bus travel to encourage them to use local stores instead of shopping online.Rebecca Long-Bailey vowed that  Labour get into power, shoppers will be offered a string of goodies to lure them back to the high street.The party’s plan would see firms banned from charging fees to use cash machines.Town centres would also be equipped with free WiFi so shoppers can stay connected at all time.And everyone under the age of 25 would be allowed unlimited free travel on the bus network.Speaking at the Labour conference in Liverpool, Ms Long-Bailey said: “Our high streets need saving from a slow and agonising death.As part of our plan to rebuild Britain and breathe le back into our communities, Labour will scrap ATM charges, deliver free WiFi to town centres, introduce a register of empty properties, provide free bus travel for under 25s and overhaul the broken business rates system which is hammering retail.Boarded-up shops and deserted high streets are a result of years of neglect and austerity.Our country needs to radically change course so our towns can thrive again.”A number of high street giants have recently run into trouble as the rise of web shopping has encouraged people to stay at home rather than heading to town centres.

title: jet2 emergency flight diverted france
story: A British Airways flight from London to Calgary made an emergency landing after the cockpit reportedly filled with fumes and pilots were left needing oxygen masks.Fire crews raced to the runway at Iqaluit Airport at around 5pm local time after the plane was erted to Nunavut, Canada.

title: dame helena morrissey freedom of expression is key to diverse workplaces
story: Too often, workplaces superficially "include" people by avoiding overt bias, but at the same time encourage people to fit in, to submerge their dferences. That's the opposite of true inclusion.Welcoming erse views shows everyone that they matter, as well as helping organisations create the breakthrough moments, to solve problems, or see how to capture opportunities.The examples when I've felt really included have been when the whole decision-making process has been built around encouraging ersity of perspective. It's not been an afterthought, a self-conscious "let's make sure we've heard the woman in the room".When you reach the place where everyone wants to know what their colleagues really think because they have dferent backgrounds, experiences, qualities - and levels of seniority - you stop thinking rather articially about "identity" and have a really inclusive environment, as partners.

title: how does a second brexit referendum actually happen
story: Aside from whether or not this is a desirable outcome - of course many voters feel they have already had their say and want politicians to get on with making the best of it - could it actually happen and how?:: Is there time?We are leaving the EU on 29 March, 2019, barely six months from now.Mrs May is expected to secure an agreement - or, less likely, to deliver on her threat to walk away without one - at a special EU council meeting in November. Parliament must vote on it by early next year. Time, therefore, is short.A referendum requires legislation through Parliament.The EU Referendum Act paving the way for the vote in June 2016 took seven months to get through both Houses, after wrangling about the wording of the question, the franchise and the campaign period.Official campaigns were then designated and the actual vote was held six months after that.All the campaign groups for a second poll concede that the government would need to ask the EU for an extension to Article 50. A former EU official tells me extra time is much more likely to be granted for a second referendum than, for example, a general election, but the EU would want it "done and dusted" before the European elections in May."If it's longer than that they'll probably just want us out."The Best for Britain and People's Vote campaign groups insist that the time pressure MPs would be under would force the arrangements to progress quickly, plausibly in as little as four months after Mrs May puts her deal to Parliament.:: Why should we have it?The argument supporters make is that a lot has changed since the Vote Leave buses promised &#163350m a week, and trade secretary Liam Fox claimed a trade deal with the EU would be "the easiest deal in human history". Second vote campaigners say the Prime Minister's Chequers plan, now being attacked by Remainers as well as Leavers, was not on the ballot paper in 2016 and that therefore voters should be given the option to reconsider what is now on offer.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"

title: jeremy corbyn would be incompetent brexit negotiator poll
story: The figure was slightly more positive for Labour when asked  the party would be competent in striking a deal with Brussels.A quarter of people - 25% - agreed Labour would be competent, while 68% said it would be incompetent. story: NewsKeir Starmer gets HUGE standing ovation as he tells Labour Conference 'nobody is ruling out Remain' in Brexit voteIn an apparently ad-libbed line, Labour's Brexit chief told party faithful remain could still be an option in a people's voteShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter11:34, 25 SEP 2018Updated12:03, 25 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/politics/video/huge-standing-ovation-keir-starmer-13304548,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour activists rose to their feet in a huge standing ovation as Brexit chief Keir Starmer declared: nobody is ruling out Remain as an option in a people's vote. It was an apparently ad-libbed line, which did not appear in the original text of the speech approved by the leader's office. It provoked a deafening roar of approval from the conference floor. Conference delegates agreed a watered-down motion on Sunday night that will commit Labour to considering the option of a public vote on Brexit -  there's no deal and no general election. The next morning, John McDonnell appeared to suggest any second referendum would be about 'the deal' - hinting remain wouldn't be on the table. Instead the Shadow Chancellor said: We will be arguing that it should be a vote on the deal itself. And Unite leader and Jeremy Corbyn ally Len McCluskey said: The referendum shouldn’t be on ‘do you want to go back into the European Union?'...because the people have already decided on that.”  But Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir said: The meeting last night was very clear that the question of a public vote should be open. “We weren't ruling out options and nobody was ruling out remain. And in his keynote speech to party faithful in the main conference hall this morning, he said: We want a general election that can sweep away this failed Tory Government. And usher in a radical Labour Government that would put jobs and living standards first.    But  a General Election is not possible then other options must be kept open. That includes campaigning for a public vote. It is right for Parliament to have the first say but  we need to break the impasse, Labour campaigning for a public vote must be an option - and no-one is ruling out remain as an option. The final passage was not in the text of the speech briefed to journalists as Sir Keir took to the stage.

story: NewsLabour formally announces it's preparing to vote down Theresa May's Brexit planShadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer will give the strongest signal yet that he will order MPs to reject the deal in ParliamentShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor22:30, 24 SEP 2018Updated10:12, 25 SEP 2018NewsTheresa May won't like this one bit "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour will today formally confirm the party is preparing to vote down Theresa May's Brexit plan. Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer will give the strongest signal yet that he will order MPs to reject the deal in Parliament. Such a vote could spell catastrophic defeat for the Prime Minister - as it would see Labour join forces with Tory Brexiteers in the Commons. Sir Keir today declared that  that happens, on any rational view the government will then have to fall - triggering a general election. And on Tuesday, he will tell Labour's party conference in Liverpool: Some have said Labour could vote for any deal the Tories reach. Some have said we may abstain. Some have said we may support a vague deal – a ‘blind Brexit’ – that gives no detail about the terms of our future relationship.  So, let me be very clear - right here, right now: If Theresa May brings back a deal that fails our tests – and that looks increasingly likely - Labour will vote against it. No s, no buts. And  the Prime Minister thinks we’ll wave through a vague deal asking us to jump blindfolded into the unknown she can think again. You can’t meet Labour’s tests by failing to provide answers. Sir Keir has set six tests  that the plan must meet before Labour will back it.  But Labour is still riven with disagreement over whether to back a second referendum on Brexit. title: no deal brexit plans revealed
story: NewsNo Deal Brexit plans revealed: 9 more startling official warnings and how they'll affect your leThe government have released their final pile of warnings. Here's how they'll affect what you doShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorMikey SmithPolitical reporterDan Bloom17:12, 24 SEP 2018Updated19:04, 24 SEP 2018News "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrexiteers insisted negotiating our way out of the EU was going to be the easiest job in the world. But six months out from Brexit day it's looking more and more likely that we won't get a deal at all. And by the looks of these warnings from the government, that's going to mean a head-scratching mess of hassle, faff and red tape. Tory ministers today published their final pile of 24 papers, showing what will change for British businesses and consumers in the unlikely event of a no-deal outcome. It could cause havoc with flights and coach journeys and create a massive headache for truck drivers. And taking your pet abroad could mean a visit to the vet FOUR MONTHS ahead of time. Here are the most startling warnings from the final tranche of no-deal Brexit warnings, and what they could mean for you. 1. Taking your pet abroad? You could need to visit the vet four months in advance  The papers reveal a huge surge in red tape for pet owners who want to take their beloved animals abroad. Currently dogs , cats and ferrets can travel anywhere in the EU as long as they have a pet passport. Currently, the main requirement is that three weeks before the first visit, owners must go to the vet to have their pet vaccinated against rabies and microchipped. But in the worst case no-deal Brexit, pet owners would have to visit a vet at least FOUR MONTHS before visiting the EU. This means pet owners intending to travel to the EU on 30 March 2019 would need to discuss requirements with their vet before the end of November 2018, the papers warn. The animal would have to have a rabies vaccination followed by a blood test at least 30 days before travel, to prove the vaccination worked. Once that was completed, the pet owner would have to visit a vet to obtain a health certicate. But this cannot be done more than 10 days before the date the holiday starts. This is the worst case scenario. In another form of No Deal Brexit, the UK could be made a listed third country. This would increase red tape but not as much, with a visit to the vet only needed three weeks before travel.  British airlines hoping to fly planes between the bloc and the UK would have to win permission from each separate country, the latest Brexit technical notices said. European firms wanting to carry passengers between Britain and the continent would have to seek authority from the UK. The notice says: “In this scenario the UK would envisage granting permission to EU airlines to continue to operate. “We would expect EU countries to reciprocate in turn. “It would not be in the interest of any EU country or the UK to restrict the choice of destinations that could be served, though  such permissions are not granted, there could be disruption to some flights.” UK airlines would also lose the automatic right to fly planes between two EU destinations, such as Milan and Paris. 3. Planes might be grounded  they fail new safety checks  Planes issued with safety certicates in the UK could be grounded  European officials fail to recognise the accreditation, under a no-deal Brexit. EU officials could decide not to allow British pilots and aircraft certied by the UK's Civil Aviation Authority to operate in EU skies. Britain has said it would continue to recognise licences and certicated authorised by the Eureopan Aviation Safety Agency. But the technical notice says: “The EU has indicated that it would take a dferent approach to the UK. The information notices issued by the European Commission say that certicates previously issued by the before exit day would no longer be automatically accepted in the system after 29 March 2019.” Pilots and firms hoping to operate in the EU should consult the bloc, the note adds.  Qualications issued by CAA-approved organisations “would no longer be valid for use with EU operators after exit day”, the document warns. UK firms could also be shut out of maintenance contracts and supplying aircraft parts. 5. You might have to go through airport security TWICE  Air passengers changing flights in the EU may have to undergo two security screenings under a no-deal exit. Travellers boarding a plane in the UK to fly to a European airport before changing flights for an onward destination would be screened in Britain as now. But they might have to have a second check in the EU before getting their connecting flight. “Currently passengers flying from the UK and transferring at an EU airport for an onward flight do not have to be re-screened at that EU airport, because the UK applies, and exceeds, the EU baseline aviation security measures,” says the Department for Transport briefing note. “If there is no deal, and the EU decides not to recognise the UK aviation security system, then passengers and their luggage will have to be re-screened when changing flights in EU hub airports.” 6. Truck drivers will need new permits - and there almost certainly won't be enough to go around  Thousands of truck drivers could be locked out of EU countries as their permits to carry freight across the continent become null and void. If there's a No Deal Brexit, UK hauliers will no longer have the automatic right to be let through EU nations' borders under the current permit system. Instead,  no other deal comes into force, they have to apply for an 'ECMT' permit - and there are only a set number of these available per year. For one type of these annual permits, just 984 are issued per year, the documents say. The no deal papers warn explicitly that demand for the permits will signicantly exceed supply and firms should prepare for getting fewer than they ask for. They will be allocated through a formula that was laid down in law earlier this year, and successful applicants will be contacted at the end of 2018. Haulage firms have been warned by the government to draw up contingency plans for  they end up unable to use some of their fleet. 7. Car insurance will get more complicated  Hauliers and holidaymakers driving to the EU will be forced to apply for a 'green card' to prove they have the right car insurance. The certicates are free of charge and available from insurance companies. But the government warns firms may increase administration fees in order to cope with the extra bureaucracy. Those who forget their green cards would be forced to buy expensive frontier insurance in the country they are visiting.  Meat and animal product imports from the EU, but which originate outside the EU, would be subject to additional checking at Border Inspection Posts. The government says staff will be trained to “minimise the impact” of the increased number of import checks, and “reduce the chance of delays.” 9. UK coach operators may lose access to the EU

title: children branded fussy eaters actually
story: NewsChildren branded 'fussy eaters' may actually have genuine food intolerance, top scientist saysDr Gill Hart claims symptoms can take 72 hours to appear, making it very dficult to pinpoint the offending foodShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJon HarrisNeil Murphy09:44, 25 SEP 2018NewsSymptoms of food intolerance may include tummy pain, bloating, wind and diarrhoea "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChildren branded 'fussy eaters' may actually have a genuine food intolerance, according to a top scientist. Research shows one in four toddlers in the UK refuse food every day but biochemist Dr Gill Hart claims parents should not automatically assume youngsters are being ‘picky’. Dr Hart, scientic director at Yorkshire food intolerance testing firm YorkTest, believes a young child refusing to eat certain foods may be their way of communicating an underlying intolerance which they can’t express in words.  She sad: “It’s important parents realise that a fussy eater can sometimes have underlying food intolerances .  A child can lose their appetite because they may not be able to articulate to their parents that they are getting tummy pains.  And  a child does complain of having a sore tummy, it’s very dficult for the parent to recognise that this may be caused by the food they are eating. “Also, quite often a child might call their symptoms tummy pains, when they are in fact suffering bloating or bowel problems.” Research suggests some of the most common food intolerances are reactions to dairy products, chocolate, eggs, food additives, strawberries, citrus fruits and tomatoes. Symptoms include tummy pain, bloating, wind, diarrhoea, skin rashes and even itching. Food intolerances are dferent to allergies, which affect the body’s immune system and often cause almost instant reactions. In contrast, intolerances can take 72 hours to appear, making it very dficult to pinpoint the offending food. Dr Hart warns that just because a child doesn’t experience a gut reaction to a food doesn’t mean they are not having a reaction to it. The effects of a food intolerance can be wide-ranging.  She says it’s all down to the food-specic IgG antibody, which YorkTest measures to determine reactions to possible problem foods, revealing: “If you have got any sort of imbalance, the reactions you get with an IgG reaction can cause inflammation and the inflammation could then cause a range of problems in dferent parts of the body. “It’s not necessarily related to the gut. It depends on that person’s makeup. “And when the trigger food is removed from a child’s diet, the ‘fussy’ child could then develop a healthy appetite because he or she is not frightened about eating foods that result in tummy ache. “In a sense, you can ‘grow out of’ a food intolerance. Once the food has been identied as a problem, the first step is to remove the food that’s causing the inflammation, because it could be presenting a range of dferent symptoms.  “And our nutritional therapists can work with people to help heal their guts, frequently using probiotics that can reinoculate the gut with lots of good bacteria. “They can also offer things like digestive enzymes which can really help you break down your food properly. “And then, once you have removed the foods that are triggering the reaction and you look after your gut as well, you may start to tolerate the foods which have previously caused problems. “For me, it’s all about choice. With the right information, people have the knowledge of what works for them and what doesn’t. “It is then a balance between the reaction and the impact it has on you.” Figures released by Allergy UK in 2009 estimated as many as 45 per cent of Brits could be affected by food intolerance. ow’s milk is one of the most common childhood food intolerances.

story: NewsFinal Facebook post of dad who killed himself when missed council tax payment spiralled to £72,000 debtNigel Hurst's death is even more tragic as he had overcome cancer - having been given 12 months to live 15 years agoShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmber Hicks11:41, 25 SEP 2018Updated13:25, 25 SEP 2018NewsNigel Hurst pictured with his daughter Jessica "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA selfless dad too ashamed to admit he had debts of more than &pound70,000 wrote a tragic final Facebook post before his body was found hours later by bailfs. Nigel Hurst, who survived kidney cancer despite being given 12 months to live 15 years ago, tragically took his own le after one missed council tax bill grew to &pound1,500 and then spiralled out of control. He wrote a suicide note to his children hours before bailfs were due to evict him and repossess his house, which he had been living in without heating or water as he could not afford it. And he posted on Facebook: Goodnight sweet world. Daughter Jessica Hurst had been scrolling through her feed during a break from opera rehearsal when she saw the message from father Nigel and paused. She thought it was odd and commented Have you been hacked? Lol and went back to practise. However, hours later when she checked her phone again she saw missed calls from her mother and grandmother. She rang her mum back, who told her: Your dad's gone.  Jessica, 25, collapsed onto the floor. Her 56-year-old father, who lived in Lindale, Cumbria, had killed himself as could no longer go on. He had left notes in the house, including one at the bottom of the stairs for the bailfs telling them which room he was in. Nigel also left letters for daughters Jessica and Sally, 20. They had no idea of the extent of his money troubles as he had hidden it from them. Jessica bravely shared the note in a plea for more humanity from debt collectors. “It breaks my heart to write this. I love you with all my heart, wrote Nigel, who loved the community he lived in and would organise events such as bonfires and barbecues. I have been so unhappy in my personal le for so long, I cannot go on. Now I am about to lose my house as well as my self respect, I have decided to go.” He added: “Do not grieve for me for long. Passing for me will be a huge relief. I love you both and will always be with you.” Now Jessica is speaking out to highlight her dad's tragic case as she also wants to help others. She said: No young person should be left without their father because of a few thousand pounds of debt.  Recalling the moment she visited her father's house following his death in October, Jessica was told by a bailf You'll be shocked, reports the BBC . Inside she found bankruptcy letters, court letters and other notices on table tops, kitchen surfaces and stuffed in plastic Co-op bags. She told the BBC: Until he died I hadn't realised my father had been in debt, let alone declared bankrupt. Three days earlier he had dropped me off in Glasgow and helped me move into a flat, ready to start the second year of my master's degree. He had stayed with me all day, helping me to unpack, and called me three times on his journey back home. It was the last time I saw him. She later found out that Nigel, who acted as an agony aunt to pals, had been living without water or heating as he could not afford it. Nigel's money problems began in 2008. It started off with &pound1,500 debt owed for council tax to South Lakeland District Council. Over time it spiralled to &pound72,000 due to interest, agent fees and legal costs. In total he owed more than &pound9,300 to the council. He was also declared bankrupt. The rugby fan never disclosed his money problems to his daughters as he was a private man, and Jessica believes her father would have seen asking for help as being a failure.  A coroner in March ruled Nigel's death on October 4 was suicide. Jessica said: “This debt pushed my father in to taking his own le. It is utterly disgusting and inhumane. The amount of pressure that had put on him was unbearable. No human being was going to withstand that as well as having cancer. It is just not fair.” She added to the BBC: I understand that my dad didn't reply to the council's letters and that must have been frustrating. But  a client has been a good citizen, paid his council tax all his le and then suddenly stops, there must be something wrong. I believe that in those circumstances the council should try to reach out to that person. Jessica believes her father was failed by the council and thinks it should have done more to help him, rather than just continue to send letters. She says the first person to turn up to his house and talk about the money he owed was a bailf. The council says it did not have a telephone number for Nigel to talk to him. The debt has since been reduced, but student Jessica and her unemployed sister do not have the money to pay it and know their family home will be sold.

story: NewsLaura Plummer 'devastated' after losing appeal to overturn jail term for smuggling painkillers into EgyptThe 34-year-old from Hull said she 'just wants to come home' after judges upheld her three-year jail term for carrying 290 tramadol tablets into the countryShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLucy ThorntonNatalie Evans22:57, 24 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/brit-jailed-egypt-smuggling-painkillers-12375491,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Jailed Brit Laura Plummer has spoken of her devastation after her latest bid for freedom was rejected by judges in Egypt .  The 34-year-old penned a heartbreaking letter from prison - saying she 'just wants to come home'. The former shop worker from Hull was jailed on Boxing Day last year for carrying hundreds of painkillers in her suitcase. She hoped the Egyptian appeal court would accept that she had no way of knowing the tramadol pills were banned.  But she was left in tears after judges in Cairo upheld her conviction and three-year prison sentence, The Sun reports .  Laura's Egyptian husband Omar Saad, 34, broke the news to her inside the notorious Al Qanater prison, where she is living in a squalid cell with 20 other women in 34C heat.   In a handwritten letter, given to The Sun , Laura said: I was sure they would see sense. This whole situation is just ridiculous. I just want to come home.  She also hit out at the UK Foreign Office, who she says refuses to intervene on her behalf. She added: How can they leave me in here? Laura was sentenced to three years in prison for carrying 290 tramadol tablets into the north African country while on holiday in October 2017. She was arrested and charged despite her pleas that the painkillers were for husband Omar’s bad back.  Speaking to The Sun, Laura said: What don’t these people get? I wonder  I’ve died and this is hell. What did I do that was so wrong in my le to end up here? I thought the appeal judges would see sense and realise I couldn’t have known the tablets were banned. It’s just so absurd.  Her older brother Kirk recently told of the “emotional rollercoaster” the whole family have been on since she was imprisoned. In an interview with Viking FM, Mr Plummer said: “I wouldn’t wish what me and my family are going through on anybody, nobody. “No one wants to see their daughter or sister in prison and  it happened to them then they would realise just how bad it is.  “But what we are going through is nothing compared to what Laura is going through in prison out there. “You sometimes just sit and think and it hits you again that she is still there and as a family we are trying to get on and lead a normal le but it’s hard and you are constantly reminded that she is still there with 20 other women sat on a cell floor. “The last six months have been an emotional rollercoaster and you get ups and downs. “One minute you are angry she even went to Egypt and then you get mad that she’s been arrested for what she did.”  Shortly into her imprisonment, one of Laura’s sisters, Jayne, revealed how Laura had been “kicked and punched” in jail and said she would be “amazed”  her younger sister survived her three-year ordeal. She was moved and is now being held in Qanatar Prison on the outskirts of Cairo.

story: NewsMum with locked-in syndrome who couldn't even breathe unassisted finally able to tell husband 'I love you'Norma Cullen, 69, developed rare neurological condition Guillain-Barré Syndrome after complications from a tummy bugShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLouie SmithFiona Duffy21:07, 24 SEP 2018Updated10:26, 25 SEP 2018NewsNorma, pictured with husband Phil, described being in a bubble as she was struck down with the condition "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA women who could not communicate for four months except by blinking finally regained her voice and told her husband: “I love you.” Keen cyclist Norma Cullen, 69, suffered locked-in syndrome after complications from a tummy bug. Paralysed and unable even to breathe unaided after developing the rare neurological condition Guillain-Barr&eacute Syndrome, the grandmother emerged from weeks of sedation unable to move anything but her eyes. She said: “You really are locked in. It’s like you’re in a bubble. “To have all these thoughts and not be able to express them was the height of frustration.”  At first her family used an alphabet board to help her spell out what she wanted to say. But it could take half an hour to finish a sentence, so she started to spell out just one word then blink yes or no to questions. Gradually Norma began to improve, able to move her head, shrug and smile. Finally doctors fitted a speaking valve to the tracheotomy through which she was being ventilated – and she saved her precious first words for husband Phil, 69. Norma from St Ives, Cornwall, recalled: “When Phil came in I said, ‘I couldn’t tell you yesterday but I can today. I love you.’

title: nurse 22 who treated children
story: NewsNurse, 22, who treated children injured in Manchester Arena bombing hanged herself weeks laterClara Malagon, 22, had been struggling with self doubt and bouts of depression, an inquest heardShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmy Walker08:48, 25 SEP 2018Updated09:11, 25 SEP 2018NewsShe was adored by her family and friends  Ltd"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dedicated young nurse who battled to save the lives of children injured in the Manchester Arena bombing took her own le weeks later, an inquest heard. Clara Malagon, who had been struggling with self doubt and bouts of depression for some time, had been on-duty on the night of the atrocity. She witnessed first-hand horric injuries sustained by the young victims, but the 22-year-old successfully underwent counselling and had a detailed debrief about the bombing with senior doctors afterwards. However, in July last year just seven weeks after the tragedy, Miss Malagon was found hanged at her Manchester city centre apartment.  It is not known why she killed herself. An inquest this week heard Miss Malagon from Twickenham, south west London had completed a degree in nursing at Manchester University and became a critical care nurse at Manchester Royal Infirmary in 2016. She was a keen rower and enjoyed cycling, running and walking and also played the viola and took up ballet and flamenco dancing. But Miss Malagon also suffered bouts of depression and self doubt and had been prescribed the antidepressant Citallipram.  Her father Dr Ignacio Malagon, a consultant anaesthatist at Wythenshawe Hospital wept as he told the Manchester hearing: She was physically quite tough but she was seeing her GP for mental health issues - we talked about it regularly. She was good at taking instructions from her GP and we talked about counselling. Out of the blue she started crying at university, she would come to me but I couldn't give her professional advice so I advised her to go and talk to someone. She went to counselling organised by university - everything was going well so she came off the medication. But in January last year she started crying again, and she said to me 'Dad, I need help.' After she had been to the GP she was told it was going to be three months before she was going to get any counselling, she said she couldn't wait for three months and said she wanted to go private.  She found one counsellor but she didn't like them. We were talking about money and I offered to help her out. I gave her some money to pay for the first few sessions and she found one she did like. She was able to organise the counselling herself. She said she was happy with the lady she found. He added: Clara was a staff nurse but she had done a training course in intensive care. She was on duty in May last year during the Arena attack. It was traumatic for her and I rang her, I was in hospital too, and I said to her: 'Are you OK?' And she said: 'Yeah Dad, it's really tough, I've seen some of the kids didn't make it.' We had a long chat and I said to her that I realise this is very traumatic for her and  she was upset then she should tell her seniors, or  she felt unwell she should tell her managers. I just said to her not to worry and that it was going to be fine.  A few days after there was a debriefing provided by the MRI. She rang me afterwards and said there had been 50 people there including her seniors and management. Everyone there told how wonderful the team had worked and she was delighted. We talked on a regular basis, either over a glass of wine or dinner. If she had an issue she would talk about it to me in a professional manner  it was to do with work. I was involved  she wanted to talk about anything. She would tell me about the patients she helped, she never said she felt understaffed or overworked. She shared everything with me. I had a very good relationship with my daughter.  When she felt stressed she would share it and talk with me. In the weeks leading up to her death, there were none such conversations. On the weekend before she was due to come for her dinner. She said she was on the train and she was very busy with things and she had been visiting a friend in London - there was no dference in her at all. Miss Malagon's flatmate Grace Callaghan who found her friend on her  home from work said: She had said to me she was feeling low and she made an appointment with her doctor to prescribe some more antidepressants. 'But that weekend we said we would have to have a curry night as we had not seen each other properly. She was one of the loveliest people I ever knew - on the night before there wasn't any concern about her. GP Dr Gill Aitken said Miss Malagon had been prescribed Citrallipram but in September 2016 she came off it and finished her nursing degree.  In a statement Dr Aitken said: She came back to me and said she was feeling low and crying, and feeling apathetic. Whilst there was no trigger, I believe this was work related. She was anxious about work, she had her own self doubt and confidence issues and she said she wasn't sleeping. But she denied any suicidal thoughts. She said she wanted some medication and I suggested a review in two weeks time, which she did. She said she had been back to Spain for a few weeks but she felt upset and felt guilty for not being a happy person to be around at the time. She had contacted a Manchester self help group. I asked  there were any issues at work and she said there had been some complex patients. She said she had no suicidal thoughts. She told me her family were a strong protective factor for her. I told her who to contact  she felt in crisis and said  she needed anything she could make an emergency appointment with the team.  Police examined Miss Malagon's iPad and laptop but found no evidence she would take her own le - with one message to a friend in a social media chat saying she had a successful counselling session. Recording a conclusion of suicide, Coroner Andrew Bridgman said: Clara had her full professional le ahead of her. Her father has told me that she was a fit and active young woman who had lots of hobbies. But it is clear from the evidence that she had mental health issues from around 2016 which correspond with her final year of her degree. She was on medication for around 6-7 months, to which she came off it and appeared to be fine. However this resurfaces towards mid June 2017 - three to four weeks following the Manchester Arena tragedy when she was on duty. It clearly had some effect on her however I have had a discussion with her father, and there was no specic reference to the trauma of the events of that night. She sought therapy and she did take private counselling, and found this helped her. Clara did intend to take her le but this inquest cannot answer why.
